comments:

Which version of 3.0 were you using?  There has been a lot of work in this 
area just recently.  If you are using a pre-M6 version of 3.0, could you try 
and repeat this problem with a 3.0 build which is M6 or later?

Does the problem still occur if you disable the JIT?
e.g. add the following the end of your eclipse command line:
-vmargs -Djava.compiler=none 

Be sure to add this at the end, since everything following -vmargs is passed to 
the VM, not Eclipse.

I am running 3.0M6.

Turning off JIT did fix this problem, as well as other Eclipse stability issues
I was having with the IBM's JDK.  Does that mean IBM Java is not suitable for
running Eclipse?  (I was having stability issues with Sun's Java on Linux, which
is why I switched to IBM Java in the first place.)

There are several known stability issues with the IBM VM's JIT when running 
Eclipse.  The Sun VM was thought to be stable.  Do you have any reproduceable 
crash scenarios on the Sun VM?

No, I don't have anything easily reproducible for the Sun's VM.  In that case
the stability problems only appear when I load my native code libraries into the VM.

For the problem with the IBM VM, could you please supply the results of running 
java -version?

Does this happen every time?  E.g. start eclipse, open a Java editor => crash?
If not, can you provide steps to reproduce it?
*** Bug 49661 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The NPE occurs when one changes the view/editor, but not in every case.

It is somehow related to the left-most Coolbar containing the back/forward-buttons.

Created an attachment (id=7373)
pic showing the missing label

Showing the missing label.

This bug could caused by the missing label of the EditorNavigationActionSet

If it's related to the missing label, I wouldn't expect that behaviour to 
change depending on whether you're running the JIT or not.

It now happens instead of the former NPE w/ the same characteristics.

To improve the performance hit from disabling the IBM JIT, it can be 
selectively disabled by setting environment variables, e.g.

set JITC_COMPILEOPT=SKIP{org/eclipse/jface/action/CoolBarManager}{*}
or
set JITC_COMPILEOPT=SKIP{org/eclipse/jface/action/*}{*}

and/or by disabling certain optimizations, e.g.

JITC_COMPILEOPT=NMMI2JIT 
JITC_COMPILEOPT=NINLINING   
JITC_COMPILEOPT=NQOPTIMIZE 
JITC_COMPILEOPT=NALL 
JITC_COMPILEOPT=NOTHER
JITC_COMPILEOPT=NGLOBAL

You might have to use export, not just set, depending on which shell you're 
using.

The stack trace in comment #11 is very strange.  It looks like it's 
encountering a disposed coolbar when switching between editors.  However, the 
coolbar should exist for the lifetime of the window.

Does this failure also go away when running without the JIT?
Or does the SWTException still occur when using the Sun VM?

pic showing icon

Did some further testing.

The perspective icon is not the "regular".

Could it be that this is the culprit of the widget disposed error?

I'll try with the JIT turned off and w/ Blackdown ... Sun JDK is not presently
installed on my system.

I can easily reproduce this error by just opening two files and repeatly
switching between them via the forward/back buttons.

disabling JIT works

set JITC_COMPILEOPT=SKIP{org/eclipse/jface/action/CoolBarManager}{*} -> still
same problem

JITC_COMPILEOPT=NMMI2JIT -> same problem

JITC_COMPILEOPT=NINLINING -> Eclipse hangs

java version "1.4.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build Blackdown-1.4.1-01)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build Blackdown-1.4.1-01, mixed mode)

-> Eclipse hangs

The wrong icon still shows w/ JIT disabled so I've opened bug 49726.
forgot to mention that I used the JIT options w/ IBM JKD :)
